I am prepared to transform into the heist mastermind known as the Night Prowler.

Recruiting and coordinating a team for a high-stakes burglary is an art in itself—more intricate than the heist itself. A team is only as strong as the bonds between its members, and trust is the most fragile and most valuable currency in our world.

First, I’d start with the muscle. I look for someone with a quiet confidence, someone who can take a punch and give one back without flinching. But it’s not about brute strength—it’s about the ability to remain calm under pressure, to blend into a crowd or part of one with a single, well-timed move. I’ve used ex-boxers before, but more often, I go for those who’ve served in the military or police—people who’ve seen the worst and still keep their heads.

Next, the tech expert. This is the silent wizard of the operation. They don’t need to be flashy or talk much. What they need is an obsession with systems—security grids, surveillance loops, network backdoors. I’ve spent years building a network of people who’ve been on the wrong side of the law but are brilliant in their own right. Some I’ve met in prison. Others, I’ve tracked through underground forums and black-market auctions.

Then, the inside man. This is the most delicate part. I don’t go for someone who’s in trouble and needs money. That kind of person is a liability. I look for someone with access, someone with a grudge or a dream that’s bigger than their fear. A disgruntled employee, a former security contractor, a high-ranking official with a secret. I find them through careful observation, subtle conversations, and a little bit of manipulation. Sometimes, they come to me. Sometimes, I have to wait years for the right moment.
